thread.title: These Are The Insane G-Forces That An IndyCar Driver Experiences At An Oval Track
thread.title_full: These Are The Insane G-Forces That An IndyCar Driver Experiences At An Oval Track

author: Alanis King on Black Flag, shared by Alanis King to Jalopnik
title: These Are The Insane G-Forces That An IndyCar Driver Experiences At An Oval Track
text:
Go to permalink Image via IndyCar on YouTube 
Over the past few days, the Verizon IndyCar Series has been out testing for the upcoming season at Phoenix International Raceway. The G-forces on the cars are insane enough to put a hurting on a GoPro in under three minutes on track, and this video lets you see just how intense it is to lap an oval in an Indy car. Advertisement 
For context, Phoenix International Raceway is a low-banked, one-mile oval in Avondale, Arizona. It’s on the shorter and flatter side as far as American oval tracks are concerned, with 11 degrees of banking in the first and second turns, nine degrees of banking on the backstretch as well as in the third and fourth turns, and three degrees of banking on the front stretch. 
The varied banking and unique track layout at Phoenix International Raceway produce a wide range of G-forces that driver Graham Rahal says top out at around 5.38 G’s in the first turn , and it’s quite fun to watch from a driver’s perspective. Here’s video of Rahal making a few laps out there: 
Both IndyCar’s YouTube channel and social accounts have tons of coverage from the weekend, including live broadcasts and archives from full test sessions. Go forth and watch racing, friends. Recommended Stories
